Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Garden State LSAMP (GS-LSAMP) will build upon the findings and successes realized in the Phase I implementation. GS-LSAMP achieved its 5-year goal in Phase I of doubling the number of STEM Baccalaureate degrees earned by students historically underrepresented in STEM disciplines in just four years by developing a transformative system of recruitment and retention based primarily upon innovative use of online education resources, research experiences, and best practices. In Phase II, the transformative system of practices will be enhanced by focusing on two critical transition points for students: (1) community college to a four-year institution in STEM and (2) STEM baccalaureate program to graduate school in STEM. The overall goal is to enhance pathways for students in STEM disciplines to seamlessly transition through a baccalaureate program and into STEM graduate programs or STEM careers. Focusing on these two critical transition points will allow GS-LSAMP to continue to be successful in producing students who are well-prepared and well-qualified for admission into STEM graduate programs and the STEM workforce, thereby improving the diversity of the workforce and enhancing the nation's global competitiveness.

For the first transition point, effective practices of GS-LSAMP will be expanded into a consortium of five nearby community colleges all of which are Hispanic-Serving Institutions (HSIs) and primary feeders to the alliance. A new designation has been developed making them Associate Members of the Garden State LSAMP. Associate membership will aid the community colleges in instituting the practices that made the Garden State LSAMP successful. Through a series of interactions and sharing of resources, a new and seamless transition model from community colleges to four-year institutions will be developed for students historically underrepresented in STEM. For the second transition point, GS-LSAMP will encourage and facilitate the transition of LSAMP scholars into graduate school and research careers by integrating research and international experiences into the undergraduate academic program. The goal is to greatly increase the percent of graduating LSAMP scholars who attend graduate school and consider pursuing careers that involve research. International experiences will be offered by pooling all of the opportunities from across the alliance to find the best fit for individual student needs. GS-LSAMP's structured program, which will "guide scholars along the entire path from first interest in a STEM discipline all the way to a career", will build knowledge about how to develop a strong regional alliance and can become a model for other alliances (consortia of institutions) to replicate for the success of a diverse and talented group of students.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University Newark
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Garden State LSAMP (GS-LSAMP) was established in 2009 with Phase II of the program beginning in 2014. In northern New Jersey, the underrepresented minority (URM) groups are primarily African Americans and Latino/Hispanic Americans. During Phase II, GS-LSAMP was comprised of 8 colleges and universities including Rutgers University-Newark (lead institution, RUN), Essex County College (ECC), Farleigh Dickinson University (FDU), Kean University (KU), Montclair State University (MSU), New Jersey City University (NJCU), Rutgers University-New Brunswick (RUNB) and William Paterson University (WPU). All are Hispanic Serving Institutions (HSI) except RUNB. Additionally, ECC is a Predominantly Black Institution (PBI), and RUN is an Asian American Native American Pacific Islander-Serving Institution (AANAPISI). 

A major goal of GS-LSAMP Phase II was to build pipelines for GS-LSAMP scholars from community colleges to 4-year schools and from Baccalaureate programs to graduate study.  The 4-year schools of GS-LSAMP doubled the baseline number of 488 STEM Bachelor?s degrees awarded to URM students by Year 4 of Phase I and tripled that number by Year 5 of Phase II (Graph 1). By the end of Phase II, 3,600 GS-LSAMP students had received STEM Bachelor?s degrees. 

By working closely with the community colleges of the Northern New Jersey Bridges to the Baccalaureate (NNJ-B2B) program, the rates of URM STEM students transferring into GS-LSAMP universities from NNJ-B2B schools rose about 190% between 2012 and 2018 compared to less than  140% for URM STEM transfers into New Jersey and US universities (IPEDS data) over the same period. The four most collaborative GS-LSAMP universities in with the NNJ-B2B, experienced URM STEM transfer rates increase nearly 210% over 2012 (Graph 2).

Not only did joint programming with NNJ-B2B significantly increase URM STEM transfers, it also contributed to the creation of an expanded learning community across all alliance campuses. They collaborated on research opportunities, the annual research conference, a transfer admissions fair and student panel discussion, speaker and workshop series, a research opportunities fair, an annual innovation team competition and cross-campus peer mentoring. These activities provided students opportunities to meet students from other campuses from across both alliances. 

Offering organized research as an integral part of the undergraduate experience was another major goal of GS-LSAMP Phase II. This has been a hugely successful program, providing students with vital laboratory experience and expertise while also building relationships with graduate students, post-doctoral fellows and faculty members. These relationships provide a support system for academic success as well as role models to encourage GS-LSAMP scholars to pursue graduate studies. The number of research opportunities offered by GS-LSAMP member reached 209 in the 2019 academic year and, despite the pandemic shut down, 300 research opportunities were offered in the 2020 calendar year. 

The GS-LSAMP continues to increase the number of URM members, students, graduates, graduate students, and professionals in STEM fields through comprehensive programming that provides laboratory skills, leadership and teamwork experiences, academic and emotional support, and network development, thereby providing a model for institutions and alliances. 


Last Modified: 08/02/2021
Modified by: Alexander E Gates
